title: 108_hr1382
content: The Act may be cited as the "EMTALA Regulatory Improvement Act of 2003" and includes improvements to EMTALA. The EMTALA Regulatory Improvement Act of 2003 includes amendments regarding notification of providers when EMTALA investigations are closed and prior review by peer review organizations in cases involving termination of participation. The EMTALA Regulatory Improvement Act of 2003 includes amendments requiring the Secretary to request a review before terminating a hospital's participation for violations related to medical screening, stabilizing treatment, or appropriate transfer. A 5-day review period must be provided, and a copy of the organization's report must be given to the hospital or physician. The EMTALA Regulatory Improvement Act of 2003 includes amendments that impose requirements on organizations for terminations of participation, with an effective date after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 3. EMERGENCY MEDICAL TREATMENT AND ACTIVE LABOR ACT (EMTALA) TECHNICAL ADVISORY GROUP. The Secretary will establish a Technical Advisory Group (Advisory Group) to review EMTALA issues. The group will consist of 19 members, including representatives from hospitals and practicing physicians in relevant fields. The Advisory Group for EMTALA issues will consist of 19 members, including representatives from various medical specialties, patients, staff from different regional offices of CMS, and individuals from State survey offices and peer review organizations. Members will be selected based on nominations from organizations representing providers and patients. The Advisory Group for EMTALA regulations will review and provide advice on regulations, solicit feedback from hospitals, physicians, and the public, and disseminate information. The group will elect a chairperson and hold meetings as directed by the Secretary. The Advisory Group for EMTALA regulations will meet twice a year and as needed, terminating 30 months after its first meeting. The Secretary can establish the group despite any limitations on advisory committees.
